markdownRemark.html:
After deciding to transition away from Medium and launch my own blog, the next decision to make was selecting a publishing platform.

I have dabbled with creating a custom blogging platform before, leveraging Markdown files and various APIs, but I don’t have confidence in my own ability to make something resilient from scratch in a reasonable time period.

In looking for a self-hosted platform that would satisfy my needs, I considered the following options:

  • Ghost
  • Wordpress
  • Jekyll
  • Gatsby

Ghost

Ghost is a neat little publishing platform about which I have heard good reviews. I would have enjoyed the opportunity to flex my Node muscles when developing. However, I’m not interested in paying for a platform at this time.

Wordpress

Story time: when I was in high school, I started a web design and development company with a classmate. My partner quickly picked up Wordpress development and wanted to use it on all our projects. But try as I might, I couldn’t figure Wordpress out. Feeling like a failure, I stuck to project management and design.

(That business partner is now a PhD student in California using machine-learning algorithms to identify bird calls. Pretty neat!)

To this day, Wordpress remains a boogeyman for me. Even though it is a standard on the web, but I wasn’t interested.

Jekyll

Jekyll looks neat and integrates well with GitHub pages. I’m not a huge fan of HTML templating, but they seem to have streamlined things pretty well. But I have never worked in Ruby or with gems before and wasn’t looking to dive into something totally new for this project.

Gatsby

That left Gatsby, a “blazing fast” React- and GraphQL-powered static site generator. I tinked around with Gatsby a few times in the past but never got anywhere. Now with a real project in mind, I decided to go a little deeper.

The development process in Gatsby wasn’t perfect, but it felt like a natural step for a React developer. After a week working on a site, I felt ready to deploy and share it with the world.

Gatsby pros

Components

Utilizing reusable components is second nature at this point and feels more natural than templating.

Routing

Navigating in a React application can take some configuration, but Gatsby’s routing worked right out of the box. Pass a to prop to the Link component and you’re off to the races.

Hot reloading

Other development platforms may have this feature, but it works seamlessly on Gatsby. It made making changes to the template or an individual post fast.

GraphQL

This is the first project on which I have used GraphQL, and (after a few hiccups) I enjoyed the flexibility it provides. The integrated GraphiQL IDE is a brilliant idea.

Gatsby cons

Old docs mixed with new

I hesitate to put this under the cons, because the newer Gatsby docs are great. But during the development process I would regularly find myself on an older page was either out-of-date or unclear. I had to modify some code samples taken from the docs in order for things to work correctly.

Page generation

The process by which Gatsby generates it’s static pages is—at first glance—cryptic. I relied heavily on the documentation (see above) to understand the workings of gatsby-node.js, and it was only after a few days that I started to wrap my head around it.
